row.col: It has been suggested that this article or section be into . ()

This article or section needs that appear in reliable, third-party publications. s and sources affiliated with the subject of the article are generally not sufficient for a Wikipedia article. Please include more appropriate from , or discuss the issue on the talk page. (July 2008)''

bdy.p:
Security Now! is a weekly podcast hosted by
Leo Laporte
and
Steve Gibson
. It is part of the TWiT.tv network. The first episode was released on 19 August 2005.

Released each Thursday, Security Now! consists of a discussion between Gibson and Laporte of issues of computer security and, conversely, insecurity. Covered topics have included security vulnerabilities, firewalls, password security, spyware, rootkits, Wi-Fi, virtual private networks (VPNs), and virtualization. The intro theme was composed by Jamie Diamond of The MediaRight Group and the closing theme was made by Mark Blasco at podcastthemes.com

sec.p:
Security Now! is distributed via its main podcast RSS feed
(link) and on the GRC Security Now! page.1 The audio is encoded as 64 kilobit per second
MP3 files, with lower quality (16 kbit/s) versions available for listeners on low bandwidth connections (such as dial-up) or those with limited storage space.

ss1.p:
The podcast runs for approximately 1 hour, with the actual discussion of the subject of the podcast typically starting 20 minutes into the show. The first 20 minutes being spent on general chat, security news, sponsors and reading out letters and e-mails praising Steve's disk recovery product
SpinRite , although the latter is not an official sponsor of the show and its dominance in the show has been criticized.2

As part of GRC's section on the podcast, supplementary notes and transcripts of each show are available in plain text and
PDF
formats.

sec.p: Beginning from episode 16, every fourth episode (referred to as " mod 4 episodes" or "mod 4 equals 0 episodes") has been devoted to answering questions and responding to feedback provided by Security Now! listeners. The GRC web page has a feedback form allowing listeners to submit their comments and questions. Additionally, the so-called "Mailbag" episodes were added in late July 2007 to "share and discuss the thoughts, comments, and observations of other Security Now! listeners" (referred to as "mod 4 + 2 episodes").3 The distinction between "mailbag" and listener feedback episodes was removed in episode 108.

In August 2007, Security Now! won in the People's Choice
Podcast Awards
Technology/Science category. In August 2006, Security Now! ranked fourth in the "Top 40" of all podcasts listened to via the PodNova service.4 Security Now! averaged around 100,000 downloads per episode throughout 2006.56

row.col:

, one of the first wormsof 2005.
Microsoft 's Strider HoneyMonkey research project to find malicious and phishingweb sites.
Network address translation routers and how they can act as firewalls.
Various ways of creating and using a personal password"algorithm" for Internet web sites.
A wrap-up of the password topic with answers to listeners' questions.

How researchers at UC Berkeley were able to recover text typed at a keyboard through the sound made by the keys, and how CRT emissions can be used to snoop on users. http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2005/09/14_key.shtml
How and why Steve Gibson wrote one of the first spywareremoval tools.
How denial-of-serviceattacks are being used not only against large corporate sites but the average computer user also.
Rootkits, their use, detection and removal.
The privacy and security concerns of "open" wireless access points.

Some of the less secure Wi-Fi security methods, including
WEP
and
MAC address
filtering.
Sony 's XCP, the technology behind the 2005 Sony BMG CD copy protection scandal.

Wi-Fi Protected Access
encryption on wireless networks and the various flavours of it.
The reasoning behind virtual private networks and how they can offer security for the average user.

SSL
and
SSH
used in conjunction with virtual private networks.
Answers to questions sent in by Security Now! listeners.
Earlier VPN protocols and some of the difficulties in applying them.

Hamachi, iPIG and
OpenVPN systems compared.

Listener questions and the first word on the
Windows Metafile vulnerability
.

A special short edition concerning the WMF vulnerability and a temporary hot-fix by software developer
Ilfak Guilfanov
.

Ilfak Guilfanov
who makes a guest appearance and the impact of the WMF vulnerability.

Steve Gibson raises his concerns that the WMF vulnerability could be a
backdoor
inserted deliberately by Microsoft.
Steve Gibson's MouseTrap utility to test Windows computers for the WMF vulnerability http://www.grc.com/wmf/wmf.htm.
The fundamental technology behind the Internet.

The two main data protocols of the Internet:
UDP
and TCP.
The operation of local area networks.
The flaws in Ethernet security and the phenomenon of ARP cache poisoning http://www.grc.com/nat/arp.htm.
The social and ethical implications of cryptography.
The use and security behind stream ciphers and early decoder rings.
The fundamentals of symmetric block ciphers.

Public key cryptography such as the
Diffie-Hellman key exchange
and RSA.

How
cryptographic hashes
work and are used to verify the integrity of files and email.
Prime number generation, key recovery, and digital certificates.
Discussion of the open source file encryption program TrueCrypt.
Discussion of NAT routers and techniques for P2Pprograms to traverse them.

The
Hosts file
, and its use in privacy and spyware applications
Steve discusses whether or not router logs are useful security information.
Denial of Service Attacks and botnets.

JavaScript exploits, eBay gaming and
Hamachi 's sale to LogMeIn
VMware Player and its Virtual Machine "appliances"; use of virtualization for sandboxing
" Blue Pill" rootkit that takes advantage of next generation virtualization hardware support and is "completely undetectable".

Lighter programs for virtualization, with focus on semi freeware-semi nagware ("just" one nag once a month) and crippleware (some "extra" features can be unlocked by paying) (
Sandboxie . http://www.sandboxie.com/
Virtual PC review and why Steve thinks VMware is superior.

Vulnerability
in Vector Markup Language for
IE and
Windows 2000
NTFS
file corruption bug.

Steve and Leo closely examine the commercial multiplatform virtual machine offerings from
Parallels , comparing them to VMware and Virtual PC.

Two new
Zero day attack
Internet Explorer
vulnerabilities
and the exploration of commonly expressed privacy and security concerns presented by the need to trust Internet Service Providers.

The entire range of applications for Internet proxies and proxy servers, as well as both the benefits and the potential security and privacy liabilities created by filtering and caching web and other Internetcontent.
MojoPac from RingCube Technologies. Steve tells all about what he found and what he believes it means now and in the future.
Leo and Steve discuss the difficulties of securing Windows.

The new security features
Microsoft has designed and built into their new version of Windows,
Vista .
Vista's Kernel Patch Protection (aka PatchGuard), its limitations, benefits, and real purpose.
Is there such a thing as anonymity on the Internet? How important is it?

Two interesting implementations of Internet anonymization: The Freenet Project for anonymously storing and transmitting files, and
Tor , "the onion router" which can anonymise Internet traffic.
SecurAble, Steve's latest freeware for analyzing processor support for x86-64, the NX bit and hardware virtualization.
The history of digital rights managementand the technologies used to enforce it.

Peter Gutmann
is a guest to discuss the Advanced Access Content System for protecting high-definition content in
Windows Vista .

Premium content protection features in
Windows Vista .

Microsoft's response to
Peter Gutmann
's paper on
Windows Vista 's digital rights management.
How hardware data execution protectionworks, how to turn it on, and the possible pitfalls of using it.
An explanation of how spambots work, and how one can ascertain the original source of spam.
A discussion of the distressing results and implications of two recent very large studies of hard drive field failures.
A discussion of the interesting topic of state-sponsored Cyber Warfare.
A closer look at Windows Vista's User Account Control.
A discussion of Jikto and the cross-site scripting flaws it looks for.
Special Edition: The Animated Cursor Vulnerability
Special edition to warn and inform listeners of a serious zero-day exploit that affects NT, XP, and Vista - even if fully patched.

Updates on the Animated Cursor Vulnerability, a recommendation for security software from
eEye
, and how the Sony Reader works, plus an in depth discussion of scripting vulnerabilities.
Another common attack vector in web software is the SQL injection. Steve explains what it is and how it happens.
An in depth look at the latest security problems regarding WEP.
Marc Maiffret of eEye Digital Security
Windows and Mac security, the coming threat from web applications and Blink.
Steve and Leo discuss Software Patents.
The fourth factor of Multifactor Authentication.
Open ID, how it works and what it means to you.
The FBI says it has uncovered its findings from Operation Bot Roast.
Discussion of authentication with a look at Internet identity metasystems.
The Trusted Platform Module - a hardware solution to security now shipping on many computers.

Differentiating humans and automated clients using
CAPTCHA
.

Interview with Michael Vergara,
PayPal 's Director of Account Protections.
What Leak Tests are and how they are used.
VeriSign 's Personal Identity Provider beta and The New Perfect Passwords page.
Steve talks about his E-Commerce system, and the behind-the-scenes workings.

Steve and Leo discuss the problems and concerns surrounding
OpenID
.
Discussion of Steve's authentication system for employees of GRC.
Further discussion of Steve's authentication system for employees of GRC.
Further discussion of Steve's authentication system for employees of GRC.

Discussion of the security implications of
third-party cookies
.
Steve and Leo discuss internet privacy.

Interview with Dave Wright of JungleDisk, an application to interface with
Amazon S3
.
Steve describes the Rijndael symmetric-key algorithmin detail.
A discussion of the challenges of IT security in the enterprise.
Discussion of Windows SteadyState, a tool that gives administrators enhanced options for configuring shared computers.
Discussion of Free CompuSec, a free full disk encryption system.
Steve details the increased functionality of TrueCrypt v5.0.
Interview with David Jevans, CEO and founder of IronKey about the security-hardened IronKey USB storage device.
Steve describes the operation of static and dynamic RAM memory.
Discussion of the "cost" of using the Internet.

Steve describes the week he spent at the 2008 annual
RSA Conference
Special guest Stina Ehrensvard, CEO of Yubio, speaks about her company's new secure authentication device.
Discussion of the Secunia's Personal Software Inspector (PSI) - security vulnerability scanner.
Also includes the MS Security Assessment tool (MSAT).
Part 1 of 3 discussing some ISPs installation of customer profiling/spying hardware.
Part 2 of 3 discussing some ISPs installation of customer profiling/spying hardware.
Part 3 of 3 discussing some ISPs installation of customer profiling/spying hardware.
How DNS operates, and how the recent vulnerability discovery affects it.
Update on the security of DNS after the recent patch, and the "ultimate hack" for DNS.
Discussion of a recent analysis on security holes in Vista.
Examination of Google's new "Chrome" web browser, with an emphasis on security.

sec.p:
In episode 22 of Security Now! in January 2006, Steve Gibson made an accusation7 that
Microsoft may have intentionally put a
backdoor
into the
Windows Metafile processing code of the Windows 2000 and XP operating systems.

Gibson claimed that while reverse engineering the Windows Metafile format, he could only run arbitrary code if he used a "nonsensical" value in the metafile. His conclusion was that Microsoft had intentionally designed Windows in this way to allow them to use the feature as a backdoor to running code on Windows computers without the knowledge of the user.

Gibson's claim was refuted8 by Stephen Toulouse of
Microsoft in an
MSDN
blog posting on 13 January 2006, stating that Gibson's observations applied only to metafiles containing one data record, and that the behavior was not intentional. Gibson then apologized for the mistake, but held that the vulnerability still could not have been a coding error.

indent.it:
Further information:
Windows Metafile vulnerability
and Transcript of episode 22 of Security Now!''
